docs.abstract: The American Indian Center was near areas that were damaged in protests after George Floyd’s death, and residents are preparing for possible unrest again after a verdict.
docs.snippet: The American Indian Center was near areas that were damaged in protests after George Floyd’s death, and residents are preparing for possible unrest again after a verdict.
docs.lead_paragraph: The regular updates that Johnny Crow’s girlfriend gives him about the former officer Derek Chauvin’s trial trigger reminders of how the Native American community in Minneapolis rallied to support one another in the months after George Floyd died.

headline.main: Minneapolis’s Native American community is closely watching the trial.

docs.abstract: Philonise Floyd described his oldest brother as a “leader in the household” who had a close relationship with their mother.
docs.snippet: Philonise Floyd described his oldest brother as a “leader in the household” who had a close relationship with their mother.
docs.lead_paragraph: In brief, but tearful testimony, Philonise Floyd spoke in loving terms about his oldest brother, George Floyd, on the 11th day of testimony in the murder trial of Derek Chauvin.

headline.main: ‘He showed us how to treat our mom,’ George Floyd’s brother breaks down during his testimony.

docs.abstract: Courteney Ross, 45, said she and Mr. Floyd had started taking opioids when they were prescribed for chronic pain.
docs.snippet: Courteney Ross, 45, said she and Mr. Floyd had started taking opioids when they were prescribed for chronic pain.
docs.lead_paragraph: Courteney Ross, who was dating George Floyd for nearly three years before his death in May, delivered tearful testimony on Thursday about their shared struggle with an opioid addiction.

headline.main: George Floyd’s girlfriend described their relationship: A shared struggle with addiction, their first kiss, a ‘dad selfie.’

docs.abstract: Jane Coaston debates three proposals to fix America’s broken policing.
docs.snippet: Jane Coaston debates three proposals to fix America’s broken policing.
docs.lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin has been found guilty of the murder of George Floyd. But whatever bittersweet feelings the rare outcome elicited were short-lived, since instances of police brutality compound almost daily. There’s no debate: Policing is broken in America. But how do we fix it?

headline.main: Policing Is Not Broken. It’s ‘Literally Designed to Work in This Way.’

docs.abstract: “To continue to apply that level of force to a person proned out, handcuffed behind their back — that in no way, shape or form is anything that is by policy,” Chief Medaria Arradondo testified.
docs.snippet: “To continue to apply that level of force to a person proned out, handcuffed behind their back — that in no way, shape or form is anything that is by policy,” Chief Medaria Arradondo testified.
docs.lead_paragraph: MINNEAPOLIS — The prospect that a police chief would take the witness stand against a fellow officer is exceedingly rare. But there was the chief of the Minneapolis Police Department on Monday, condemning the actions of Derek Chauvin, the officer charged with murdering George Floyd, as wrong by every imaginable measure.

headline.main: In Rare Testimony, Chief Says Chauvin ‘Should Have Stopped’ Pinning Floyd
headline.print_headline: Chief Condemns Chauvin and Says He ‘Should Have Stopped’

byline.original: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs, Shaila Dewan and John Eligon

docs.abstract: Exhibits at the house where the writer lived in the early 1800s are being updated to add historical context. Not everyone is thrilled.
docs.snippet: Exhibits at the house where the writer lived in the early 1800s are being updated to add historical context. Not everyone is thrilled.
docs.lead_paragraph: As part of the discussion over racism that followed the police killing of George Floyd in Minneapolis last year, museums have asserted solidarity with the Black Lives Matter movement and begun to rethink and recast how they portray history.

headline.main: A Jane Austen Museum Wants to Discuss Slavery. Will Her Fans Listen?

docs.abstract: Society has become horribly desensitized to police killings of Black men.
docs.snippet: Society has become horribly desensitized to police killings of Black men.
docs.lead_paragraph: One of the first times I wrote about the police killing of an unarmed Black man was when Michael Brown was gunned down in the summer of 2014 in Ferguson, Mo. Brown was a Black teenager accused of an infraction in a convenience store just before his life was taken. Last summer, six years on, I wrote about George Floyd, a large Black man accused of an infraction in a convenience store, this time in Minneapolis.

headline.main: Rage Is the Only Language I Have Left
headline.print_headline: Rage Is the Only Language I Have Left

docs.abstract: A football player posted the image, which superimposed two Virginia high schools’ logos on the faces of Derek Chauvin and George Floyd, to celebrate his team’s victory, according to the district superintendent.
docs.snippet: A football player posted the image, which superimposed two Virginia high schools’ logos on the faces of Derek Chauvin and George Floyd, to celebrate his team’s victory, according to the district superintendent.
docs.lead_paragraph: A Virginia school district said it was investigating an image posted on social media by a high school football player that repurposed a photo of Derek Chauvin, the former Minneapolis police officer charged with murdering George Floyd, kneeling on Mr. Floyd’s neck to celebrate his team’s recent victory.

headline.main: School District Investigating ‘Abhorrent’ George Floyd Image Posted by Student

docs.abstract: Judge Peter Cahill, who has maintained that Mr. Floyd’s past actions are largely irrelevant to the case, initially said that the prior arrest could not be introduced in court.
docs.snippet: Judge Peter Cahill, who has maintained that Mr. Floyd’s past actions are largely irrelevant to the case, initially said that the prior arrest could not be introduced in court.
docs.lead_paragraph: Derek Chauvin’s defense hinges on an argument that George Floyd’s drug use, not Mr. Chauvin’s knee, caused his death. To that end, the defense asked permission to present an arrest of Mr. Floyd in May 2019 — exposing jurors to Mr. Floyd’s history of interactions with law enforcement.

headline.main: Defense focuses on George Floyd’s prior arrest and drug use.

docs.abstract: Derek Smith, the paramedic, said that he had first felt Mr. Floyd’s neck for a pulse while police officers were still on top of him and that he could not find one.
docs.snippet: Derek Smith, the paramedic, said that he had first felt Mr. Floyd’s neck for a pulse while police officers were still on top of him and that he could not find one.
docs.lead_paragraph: When a paramedic arrived at the scene of George Floyd’s arrest, he could not find a pulse and believed that Mr. Floyd was already dead, he testified in court on Thursday.

headline.main: George Floyd was dead by the time medical help arrived, a paramedic testified.
